perturbation.original_text: 2) If a Party materially breaches an obligation under this Agreement and does not cure such breach within sixty (60) days of receiving notice of such breach from the non-breaching Party, the non-breaching Party may terminate this Agreement immediately upon written notice to the breaching Party.
perturbation.changed_text: 2) If a Party materially breaches an obligation under this Agreement and does not cure such breach within fifteen (15) days of receiving notice of such breach from the non-breaching Party, the non-breaching Party may terminate this Agreement immediately upon written notice to the breaching Party.
perturbation.explanation: A 15-day cure period for a material breach is unusually short, especially considering the complexity of pharmaceutical supply agreements. German law requires reasonable notice and cure periods for breaches, especially if significant investments or dependencies are involved. A 15-day period may be deemed unreasonably short and unenforceable, particularly if it involves complex operational or regulatory compliance issues. This contradicts principles of fairness and reasonableness in German contract law.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Principles of fairness and reasonableness in German contract law related to breach of contract and cure periods.
